name: Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword
description: Sid Meier's Civilization IV®: Beyond the Sword is the second expansion pack for Civilization IV - the 2005 PC Game of the Year that has become a worldwide hit.
minimum_requirements: Windows 2000 (plus Service Pack 1 or higher), Windows XP Home or Professional (plus Service Pack 1 or higher), or Windows Vista; 1.2GHz Intel Pentium 4 or AMD Athlon processor, 256 MB RAM, 64 MB video card with hardware T&L (GeForce 2, Radeon 7500 or better), DirectX 7 compatible sound card, 1.7 GB of free hard drive space, DirectX 9.0c (included) Recommended:  1.8GHz Intel Pentium 4 or AMD Athlon processor or equivalent (or better), 512 MB RAM, 128 MB video card with DirectX 8 support (pixel and vertex shaders), DirectX 7 compatible sound card, 1.7 GB of free hard drive space, DirectX 9.0c (included)

Both the best Civilization game ever (played the retail version for thousands of hours before getting it on Steam), and the best modding platform ever. No other game has seen mods as epic as Fall from Heaven II and its numerous derivatives, Rhye's and Fall of Civilizations and Rise of Mankind.  Other game companies should learn from Firaxis and open the source code of a part of their game so modders can really add new functionality without dumb hacks.  Other modding communities would do well to learn from the culture of modmodding in the Civ community, where people build upon the work of others and improve and refine it endlessly. A true community instead of a juxtaposition of bickering inflated egos.  It also wins my personal award for the most epic and fitting title screen music of all times, Baba Yetu.

While this is not a universal truth, I believe that a strategy game where only on strategy can be used to win is in essence: NOT a strategy game. The reality is that in Civlization IV vanilla, defence is kind of possible, but needs a LOT of effort and is not ultimatly worth it because your score point generation falls off the map while producing military units you will not use to take a capital/city.   However, in BTS this is even worse because defence is not even possible. You must research knights to counter catapults? wtf. The research is only like 1000 years apart. The only stategy available in Civ IV is: ATTACK, ATTACK, ATTACK! If that is how I wanted to play then I would play a fricken RTS. (Real Time Strategy) Like AoM, Warcraft III, or Starcraft. The fact that this grind for military units is the only way to play makes all other parts of the game more like a dissapointing minigame you pursue while everyones LotR size hordes hump eachother in the field. If you pursue a science victory you essentially are achieving a military victory, but decided to make a spaceship while your nukes were in transit to your enemies loved ones.   So, once again I state: A strategy game with one strategy is not strategy game at all. Don't really want to be identified as a Civ V fan boy, but yes they fixed this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in Civ V and you can actually enjoy 5 different victory goals. (if you buy all the expansions that is, otherwise the vanilla game is the same meatgrinder of military units you wait on, while you fap or look at reddit) So, do not buy this game unless you want to have stacks of units slap eachother until one loses the strength to go on. This review is... hard, not because it's a bad game or mixed, mostly because despite how many hours I put in on it, the amount of Civ V I've played since has forced almost all of IV out of my mind. From the vague memories I have, it was a lot of fun, but V was better in every way (after V got the expansions). I would play this all the time with my ex in college back then.   But for a real review, it's Civ, if you liked II, III, or I, you'll enjoy IV. It still has stacks of doom and is a fantastic game. However nowadays V is generally preferred and recommended. IV should only be played with all the expansions as well. If I were reviewing this 8-10 years ago, I'd probably rate it even higher, but there are better games out.  9.0/10
